author: Jack Warren
title: Nigel Farage tells Piers Morgan: Politics was my calling in life | UK | News | Express.co.uk
text:
I suppose being in politics, it wasn’t a job it was almost a calling Nigel Farage 
“But I suppose, if I’m honest about it, my complete fanaticism for the Ukip thing, for the cause and I guess I did put that above everything else, there’s no question about it. 
“It’s probably a rotten thing to say but yes [it is my priority.] I suppose being in politics, it wasn’t a job it was almost a calling, it dominated my life, so I do think that probably a lot of people around me have paid quite a big price for that.” 
In the hour-long interview, Mr Farage complained about the way he had been portrayed in the UK media. ITV The former Ukip said politics had been his "calling" 
He said he had been forced “to live like a virtual prisoner” because of the liberal media trying “to demonise me and give me a bad name”. 
“Will I ever forgive the British media for what they’ve done to me? No,” he fumed. 
Morgan also quizzed the 52-year-old on whether he thought he was liked among his peers. ITV The 52-year-old said he would "not forgive" the media for the way he'd been portrayed Nigel Farage in pictures Thu, December 15, 2016 Nigel Farage is a British politician who has been the leader of the UK Independence Party since October 2016. Getty Images 1 of 48 British politician Nigel Farage arrives at Trump Tower on December 15, 2016 in New York City. President-elect Donald Trump and his transition team are in the process of filling cabinet and other high level positions for the new administration. 
The eurosceptic responded by making a dig at his EU colleagues while admitting he was “the most hated” person within the bloc. 
“I spent 17 years inside an institution trying to effectively destroy it, can you imagine how popular I am in Brussels? 
“I am the most hated figure that’s ever been in that place, every time I get up to speak hundreds of people boo and jeer. 
“Do you know what Piers? I couldn’t care less.” Related articles
